body.div:
Feby 15 th Feby 15 th 1841
My dearest mother - your most
touching affectionate letter
Fanny has [underline]this moment[/underline]
(a quarter before 4 oclock')
read to me - Conceive that from
the moment it was put into her
hands at 12 oclock when she
was dressing till this very instant
she never had one interval
to ourselves when she could
impart it to me - Such streams
of people! -- Oh I w[superscript]d[/superscript] not lead such
a life! ! [underline]could[/underline] not at my age &
such as I am for long -- I never
[underline]felt[/underline] it more than at this time
and yet the people [deletion]each[/deletion] having
each some particular reason for
being admitted which cannot
be resisted- -- Old Lady Charleville
for instance carried up these
narrow stairs by those huge men
[missing page] [/missing page]
unnecessarily painful - and
here with Fanny I felt that I
could be of some pleasure if not
some use to this beloved child
of yours When it was impossi
ble for you to be with her
But now when all is over
& you have done all for that
gentle spirit that could be done
do you not feel Dear Mother
that Fanny must be your
next object.? - It has occurred
to me that you might possibly
think of coming over with Hono
ra immediately - If this could
be do not let anything I have
said about seeing you at Edge
worths town for some days &
settling business before you set
out be any obstacle or make
any difficulty in your mind
All those business matters are
quite [underline]subordinate considerations[/underline]
and you know you can leave
directions & explanations with
[blank page] [/blank page]
[missing page] [/missing page]
less of them to day - [insertion]than yesterday[/insertion] and
has been [insertion]and is[/insertion] altogether better
she [deletion]and[/deletion] slept well last night -
Her pulse continues steadily
good & D[superscript]r[/superscript]. Ashburner told
me that he augurs that the
strength is increasing & the
spasms will go entirely
God send it may be so
your ever hopeful & perfectly
well Maria E
To Harriet Butler
My dear Harriet - Will you be
so kind to look in the Imperial
under my bed for two black
silk gowns & some rough [unclear] dried [/unclear]
net hand[superscript]s[/superscript] for mourning - and
black silk stockings - I believe
you will find - and in the
box where you found Lady EW's
candlestick some black buckle
&c - If Honora can bring them
over I should be obliged to her
- But do not ask her, if you see
that it would be a plague to
her - I have bought what is imme
diately necessary - so that
it is merely for my selfish
convenience I ask this
Feb 15[superscript]th[/superscript]. 1841
My dear Francis - I wish you
could send me twenty or
30 [deletion]guineas[/deletion] Sovereigns by
Honora [underline]that is all I want[/underline]
ME
500 more copies sent you where you please to direct
at a moments warning -
There is enough about M[superscript]r[/superscript]. [unclear] Clifton [/unclear] & Liberia & [unclear]local [/unclear]
Africa [insertion]But remember I have more to tell you of sense that I have got from [unclear]Milpman[/unclear][/insertion] - [deletion]But[/deletion] I must now tell you that poor M[superscript]rs[/superscript]. Ral-
stone's baby is crying so, screaming so that I hardly
know what I am writing - teeth! teeth! teeth!
the first and last plagues of life in first and
second childhood - I hope that my own dear
little Maria the pretty is no more tormented with
the cutting & coming of her pearly white teeth -
How different this baby from her! - But I will not
go into the differences - only I am glad that our
baby is ours - and dear Lucy, I am glad that
you have in your arms as I trust you have at
this moment fondly playing with you and
being the comfort of your life - through all -
And I hereby promise you that I will not be jealous
of you nor even angry with [insertion]the[/insertion] darling if she should
not know me when [underline]first[/underline] I come back - & [insertion]it[/insertion] should
turn away & cling to you - I will be - [underline]if I can[/underline]
as good humored and reasonable as her
own dear father was when she on his return
from Florence [underline]ignored[/underline] him
I have made a bold promise - Heaven send I may be
as good as my word -
We were not any in this house good enough to go to church
to day - because the child was so bad - But
I see a whole regiment of young men and boys from
14 to 20 - who with a full band of music playing
Rory O'More or what they please march [insertion]towards [/insertion]Church
till they get within sight & decent distance of the
church and then they stop the music -
This reg[superscript]t[/superscript]. of youths are the pupils who are being
educated for Engineers - Cavalry Infantry & artillery
at [underline]Addiscomb[/underline] E I military College which is within
view of these windows -
The surgeon who has been here this morning attending
Baby=Ralstone told us that the young Chaps at Addiscombe
play strange pranks before high Heaven and [insertion]in the face of[/insertion] the Superior
of their military college - (Sir Ephraim Stannus) This surgeon is obliged
to attend every day to inquire how the young gentlemen do
and not a day passes in which some one or other and some times
half a dozen play tricks upon him sham illness to get off their military
duties & lessons and to get on the sick list with leave of absence from school
- Some do put [unclear]lime[/unclear] upon their tongues - other some put stuff, perhaps
- for instance - 7000 thousand Irish labourers died at New Orleans [unclear]in consequence[/unclear]
of [underline]drinking[/underline] while employed in digging a canal of six miles -
NB
Remember
that I
tell you
about
[unclear] advantages [/unclear]
for Irish
of emigration
to Virginia
